don't use ignore_errors, it produces a a lot of false alarms in the logs. If you really want to ignore errors, just do "failed_when: false"

It's sounds like a hack to find out what containers have healthchecks or not. I would rather use container_config_data module to extract the names of the containers with healthcheck configuration.

- name: Generate containers configs data
  no_log: "{{ not tripleo_container_manage_debug }}"
  block:
    - name: "Find all matching configs configs for in {{ tripleo_container_manage_config }}"
      container_config_data:
        config_path: "{{ tripleo_container_manage_config }}"
        config_pattern: "{{ tripleo_container_manage_config_patterns }}"
        config_overrides: "{{ tripleo_container_manage_config_overrides }}"
        debug: "{{ tripleo_container_manage_debug }}"
      register: container_config_data
    - name: Finalise hashes for all containers
      set_fact:
        all_containers_hash: "{{ container_config_data.configs }}"

(Change the variables)

Like we did in tripleo-ansible, we create 2 facts:

container_config: "{{ all_containers_hash | dict_to_list | haskey(attribute='restart', value=['always','unless-stopped'], any=True) | default([]) }}"


container_config_healthcheck: "{{ all_containers_hash | dict_to_list | haskey(attribute='healthcheck') | intersect(container_config) | default([]) }}"

container_config_healthcheck is a list of healthcheck, e.g. ['keystone', nova_api, (...)]

/COMMIT_MSG.message: are there any inter-node dependencies with changing ptp_threshold on one host in a multinode (host) system (e.g. AIO-DX+ where one host may be upgraded first ) ?
I think this change is ok as a per host parameter.  The problem scenario involves ptp recovery on a host that is being unlocked and who's clock is far out of sync with the master.

Good question.

This parameter only affects how the clock is adjusted on the local node, and would not impact the ptp behaviour on other nodes.

This config changes addresses an issue where the clocks cannot sync because they are so far out of whack that the default behaviour of slewing the clock cannot recover. A clock that is already in sync will experience no change from this config.

So you could conceivably have a scenario where multiple nodes are out of sync and you go to upgrade them. Then you would have the upgraded node become in sync with the master and the remaining nodes out of sync until their upgrade completes.

I'm not sure if that would be a problem though? Because the nodes would have to be already out of sync for this to even come up.

Note that if this were introduced under ptp table, the 'system ptp-modify' is a system-wide parameter.

Though on a per host , the clock_synchronization parameter determines whether to use PTP or NTP.  Thus, ptp/ntp parameter changes are applied at runtime and thus can affect multiple hosts at once.  This should be verified to ensure expected behaviour.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/puppet/platf.message: Does this value need to be configurable? e.g. via 'system ptp-modify'
I don't think I'd consider this as something you'd change via ptp-modify as it applies to the host clock syncing behaviour.  Can always modify it via service parameter if there's a problem.

As per discussion, service-parameter can be used (not ptp-modify).

Please verify the step_threshold configuration change takes effect to override this value via the service-parameter; including setting back to the default value (of 0/None)

I have confirmed that service-parameter apply/modify works to configure this value even if it is a part of the default ptp_config as above.

So with this change, the system puts an entry in /etc/ptp4l.conf for
step_threshold 1.0

And then afterwards, a user can set a different value with 
system service-parameter-apply ptp global step_threshold=<value>
system service-parameter-modify ptp global step_threshold=<value>

and then use system ptp-apply to make it take effect. This triggers the runtime manifest, recreates /etc/ptp4l.conf and restarts ptp4l and phc2sys. No lock/unlock required.
The service parameter value overrides the ptp_config value.

A user is also able to set the value back to the default of 0.0 with this method.

Removing the service parameter and running ptp-apply brings back the ptp_config setting of 1.0

Because this was delegated to the admin node, it had no ssh key to use to reach the other two nodes. The key is on the undercloud but not the admin node. We probably need to pull the keys/conf files down to the fetch directory if we're going to continue with this pattern. 

(undercloud) [CentOS-8 - stack@undercloud cephadm]$ ls -l /home/stack/.ssh/id_rsa_tripleo
-rw-------. 1 stack stack 3422 Jun 20 17:22 /home/stack/.ssh/id_rsa_tripleo
(undercloud) [CentOS-8 - stack@undercloud cephadm]$

I see and this kind of failure is expected yes, because we're delegating to the node which hasn't the right keys to access the overcloud.
To make this patch work we need at least two things:

1. admin_node should be the undercloud (this solves the sync issue)
2. before pushing the files across the cluster nodes we need to fetch the content from the bootstrap node

These two steps are required to see this working.
Thanks for catching this issue!
not sure how to avoid this delegation since the playbook is run against mons[0]
@John, let's brainstorm more about this solution, we need to avoid delegation here to make things working, but I'm not sure if by doing more code here we're just introducing new potential bugs.
It's needed if the cluster name != "ceph" (so the module can use -k /etc/ceph/$cluster.conf instead of the default one)
Same here, we need this when cluster name != "ceph"
9094 is not the right default: it's the reserved altertmanager cluster port, so we need to bind the single process to 9093 (as per doc)
If this patch doesn't merge for a while, then do you want to change this port in another patch which can merge sooner?
Same here: we specify the cluster name that makes the module able to resolve the config file in the form of /etc/ceph/$cluster.conf

distributedcloud/dcmanager/orchestrator/.message: nit: this sentence is missing a word.  probably want to add 'complete'
Done

This seems like a bug in the original code. Even if we can't reach the subcloud at this point, I don't see why we would set this step to failed. I don't think we should be altering the previous result (pass/fail) of this state. Al - what do you think?
I think you are right.  If the activity was successfully applied, I dont think we would ever want this cleanup activity to set the state to something else.

I dont know if we want to claim a strategy can run to success if we cannot cleanup all the subclouds.

It might be OK, since we have code that pre-deletes previous strategies to allow new ones to be executed.

Maybe we can treat an in-accessible subcloud the same as a subcloud with no strategy, log a warning or error, and just move on.

Note:  the subcloud should not have even been in this strategy unless it was online/managed  or we used 'force'  so I would not expect it to not be available, unless the patch broke its connectivity.
Done

The strategy has already finished running at this point and will be in the complete, aborted or failed state. My comment was that I don't think we want to change that state based on what happens during the delete.
This should just be a return now that we're going to allow the strategy to be deleted.
Done
I think warn is OK - we're going to allow the delete to complete.
Done
I don't think we want to change the state of the strategy step because we couldn't delete the VIM strategy.
Done
I think this can happen if the process was restarted during the delete. This should be a debug log I think.
Done
strategy

I think you are going to need a wait loop here to wait for a period of time. The for loop above will complete once the last 100 workers are created, so this check will always fail the way it is written now.

OK,  and I think we are OK with that thread group 'stalling' if we hit a full pool.
since the subcloud_workers will eventually be cleaned up by the finally clause in the delete_subcloud code,  I would expect we are OK with some sort of loop/sleep here.


while  len(self.subcloud_workers) > 0:
  # sleep
  # maybe break out after max number of loops or sleeps
My recollection is that thread_group_manager.start will block if the thread pool is full. But that means the for loop above can exit with 100 threads running. We need to wait for those to finish.

Doesn't thread_group_manager.start  block if the thread pool is full ?

I do think a wait is required though.  
otherwise, delete will be invoked on the next pass, and all regions will be re-invoked if they ran to success (because they were deleted from the subcloud_workers in their finally clause) or that error log (worker already exists)  will be logged if they are still running.
Done

Specify how long the wait will be in the commment. I'm not sure the 100 seconds you are waiting is going to be enough for 100 parallel strategy deletes to complete. You can adjust this based on your testing I guess.
Done

Looking at Tripleo healthchecks, this seems better:

rabbitmqctl node_health_check

https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common/src/branch/master/healthcheck/rabbitmq

I can't find it in rmq docs though. There is some info on rmq health checks here: https://www.rabbitmq.com/monitoring.html#health-checks

$ rabbitmqctl node_health_check
This command is DEPRECATED and will be removed in a future version.
I think what we want is "rabbitmq-diagnostics -q check_port_connectivity"
node_health_check has been deprecated

The health checks in the doc I linked should be executed in stages:

rabbitmq-diagnostics -q ping  # stage 1
rabbitmq-diagnostics -q status  # stage 2
rabbitmq-diagnostics -q check_running  # stage 3
rabbitmq-diagnostics -q check_local_alarms  # stage 4
rabbitmq-diagnostics -q check_port_connectivity  # stage 4
rabbitmq-diagnostics -q check_virtual_hosts  # stage 5

The later stages are more complex checks, but may be less reliable. We should choose which stages to include.

https://www.rabbitmq.com/monitoring.html#health-checks

Given the complexity of this health check, we should probably make a script in the image for it.

Is the script limited to the 6 health check commands you mentioned above?
Is the final integration similar to # healthcheck_rabbitmq ping/status/check_port_connectivity?

The script should use set -e to ensure we catch any failures.
The test could just be healthcheck_rabbitmq, without args.

meta-stx-cloud/recipes-support/puppet/pu.message: Here you use BP which is BPN-PV, but this is a _git. I see that the actual .bb recipe sets PV. In other .bbappends I swa that you are using the actual full package name and version.

That's because there are several different situations between the actual directory name in the subpath in the stx repo and the recipe's BPN-PV:
1. Directory name equal to BPN-PV, BP is used. e.g. puppet-oslo-11.3.0
2. Directory name only includes package name, BPN is used. e.g. puppet-dnsmasq
3. Directory name has the same PV but different package name (the naming is different in centos and yocto), pkg-name(centos)-PV is used. e.g. puppet-postgresql-4.8.0 vs puppetlabs-postgresql
4. Directory name has different name and version. e.g. puppet-stdlib-4.12.0 vs puppetlabs-stdlib-4.18.0

So this prepares heat container images locally on the undercloud to be consumed by the cli later.  CIP does not actually fetch the images on to the system for usage, it populates the registry and generates the urls.  The actual fetching of containers and things occurs in the framework. So this is specific to the undercloud usage where we'll be running the overcloud deploy later.  standalone/undercloud already have cli params for heat container images which would be different (and not the current target).  We don't need to use CIP for those either.

> CIP does not actually fetch the images on to the system for usage, it populates the registry and generates the urls. 

Yeah, we fetch the images from local registry to the system and then tag them 'ephemeral' for overcloud deploy to find it.

I initially thought that by default we pull the images to system and then push to local registry. Looks like we copy registry-to-registry. Only in the case we want to modify the image (normally I use with cip and it confused me), we pull from local and then push to local registry again.

might be interesting to add a log here, in case there is no error above but something created the lock file?

Maybe -- but the assumed error will be ENOTEMPTY; IDK how useful the extra logging would be. I guess I could do something like

 if e.errno == errno.ENOTEMPTY:
     try:
         items = os.listdir(partition_path)
     except OSError:
         self.logger.info(
             'Error removing partition %r; directory not empty (but also not listable)',
             partition_path)
     else:
         self.logger.info(
             'Error removing partition %r; directory still has items %r',
             partition_path, items)

My expectation would be that it wouldn't be uncommon to just see one or two suffix dirs when it trips, though (and it should be the dominant case once we figure out the empty-except-for-a-lock-file issue).

I suppose this *could* also throw an EPERM -- but then, so would the replicator; I think I'd rather deal with that in the normal course of operations, rather than during some special intervention like a PPI.

Sounds reasonable. I read the related codes [1], The annotation explain that this in order to resolve a keepalived's bug. I think we can call a "send_na" method here.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/branch/master/neutron/agent/l3/keepalived_state_change.py#L93-L101
For HA router, the physical world (switch) should learn the MAC output port, the GARP is the way to refresh the forward table of the switch immediately.

Hi, Yulong: I studied the mechanism. For HA router, the ndp proxy rules set at qrouter-namespace's external gateway, and no matter master or backup router their external gateway's MAC is same, so the failover don't influence the neighbor entry of upstream router, so we needn't send neighbor advertisements, but the ndp proxy rules will be lost after multiple failover, so we need refresh ndp proxy's rule after failover. For, DVR router, the ndp proxy rules set at fip-namespace's external gateway port, the gateway ports' MAC is different at different fip-namespace, so we need send  neighbor advertisements to modify the upstream router's neighbor entry after instance migration. I will modify the spec as soon as possible.
Sorry, I don't study the mechanism, I just did a test simplely. I will to study the mechanism deeply and then come back to respond this question.

The config option "enable_ndp_proxy_by_default" can be used like this:
1. Set router gateway call API once, set ``enable_ndp_proxy=True`` another time. And L3 agent will process the router once for set router gateway, one for enable the ndp_proxy.

specs/xena/snapshot-attached-volumes.rst.message:
Since Gorka raised this in the code review -- this should define what happens if someone passes force=False to the new API microversion which allows snapshotting in-use volumes by default.

There are two options:
1) The force flag has no effect and is ignored, since under the new model there isn't anything that requires "force" when snapshotting an in-use volume

2) We assume that "force" was basically short for "snapshot in-use volumes" before, and now interpret "force=False" to mean "I purposefully _don't_ want to snapshot in-use volumes".  This means that someone passing "force=False" doesn't get the new behavior of snapshotting volumes that are in-use.

I would prefer (1) since it's straightforward and seems to make sense.
There's also option 3: don't allow force=False at all on the new microversions, which is reasonable since surely few people ever pass that.

I think what we should do is:

- the new model is that there is no such thing as "forcing" a snapshot.  If you ask for a snapshot, we'll give you one (and if crash-consistency isn't good enough for you, you should take appropriate action with your volume before creating a snapshot)

- we need to accept "force=true" in the query string because people will want to run scripts in multiple clouds, some of which will have too low a max microversion to have the new behavior available

- if someone passes "force=false" to the new mv, I think we should reject the request immediately at the API layer (i.e., don't even check to see if the volume is attached), because the new model is that there is no such thing as a forced snapshot.  This will have the side effect of satisfying the use case of passing "force=false" on the old model when you didn't want to snap a volume if it was currently attached.  (It will fail all the time, but the key thing is that someone passing 'force=false' will never get the surprise of having a successful snapshot creation, but wind up with a (merely) crash-consistent snapshot, which isn't what they wanted.)

You don't need to update unless you need to push a new patch set, but it would be good to have a memo here that (as agreed at the Xena PTG) documentation about snapshots being crash-consistent should be added to the api-ref where end users will see it.

specs/xena/temp-resources.rst.message: Yes, you are entirely correct that we don't have a reliable way to track snapshots!

What are you thinking of displaying?  I guess

  use_quota: true

In that case, the display name should probably be something like

  consumes_quota: true

But I wonder whether it would be better for users to assume that all resources count toward quota unless the response specifically indicates otherwise.  In other words, maybe only display "consumes_quota: false" to mark temporary resources, and not include the field at all on regular resources.
If it helps in testing, I'm all for it!

As you have guessed the current proposal shows "Use Quota" on the client [1] and returns "use_quota" on the server side [2].

I like the idea of changing the return and shown names to "consumes_quota" and "Consumes Quota" respectively, but I don't like the idea of only returning the value some times and not others, regardless of the expected value.  Besides my preference for explicit vs implicit here, it also helps in testing to be sure that the microversion is actually working (if all consume quota, then the microversion won't have a difference in the returned data), and it also simplifies the client code, both for the cinderclient and any other user using the rest api.

[1]: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-cinderclient/+/787407/2/cinderclient/v3/shell.py
[2]: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/786386/7/cinder/api/v3/views/volumes.py

Developers will need to pay attention to the paradigm shift in that resources now "opt in" to quotas, whereas before it was an "opt out" model.  (I completely agree with you that opt in is better and should lead to better accuracy.)

I'll try to rephrase it, since there is no paradigm shift.
By default if you create a new OVO it will consume quota, but if you explicitly say it shouldn't, then that's it.  You won't have to check multiple fields when deleting to see if quota should be removed, and code like the sync won't forget about those cases either, since seeing a "use_quota" field is quite eye catching and easy to understand and see.

castellan/key_manager/barbican_key_manag.message:
Is there a reason this would not be enabled? Is it a common design practice to make this configurable?

Later: I see nova uses the same practice so I'm guessing the answer to both questions is yes, though I don't know why.
Ack
There's some overhead involved in generating a service token with every request. Probably also backwards compatibility too, since it requires credentials to be configured for it to work.

Any particular reason to use a separate group?

Later: I assume this is based on the nova pattern. I think that makes sense there since we need _somewhere_ to put the opt that isn't 'DEFAULT', however, we already have a perfectly good 'barbican' group we could use here, right?

That's not really what I was suggesting 😊 I was pointing out that you can do this:

[some-section]
username=
password=

[barbican_service_user]
send_service_user_token=True
auth_section=some-section

I guess I can move it, although to me it makes more sense where it is now.
Ah, I misread that /o\ Thanks for moving it, even if you don't agree entirely, heh

We might want to use different credentials to communicate with barbican vs. generating a service token. It's possible to specify the name of another config section to pull the credentials from via the auth_section option, if you wanted to make them the same and avoid duplication.

Oh, of course. Thanks for the clarification. I do think the 'send_service_user_token' would make more sense in the '[barbican]' group (enable it there, then use the other group to configure it). Could we move that there as you've suggested?
I'll change it
Ack

I wonder why do we need to add these options to the [barbican] group as well, and second, this will append to the opts list in each call, if we need this, we have to copy _barbican_opts first into the local variable.

In [1]: a = [1, 2, 3]

In [2]: b = a

In [3]: a
Out[3]: [1, 2, 3]

In [4]: b
Out[4]: [1, 2, 3]

In [5]: b += [4, 5, 6]

In [6]: a
Out[6]: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]

In [7]: b
Out[7]: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]

First question: the options were added on L112, before this patch. You could argue it's a separate issue, but I'll leave it up to you whether it's worth splitting out. I suppose the main question would be whether it's worth backporting.

Valid concern here about modifying the global opts list. In practice this will only be run during config generation, but I'll fix.

I have to admit, I can't see where the session options from the [barbican] section are used, although they were present prior to this patch. Typically the auth is loaded from the request context rather than config, although config does have an affect on the client creation. It's possible we should be using load_session_from_conf_options to create the session.

For the [barbican_service_user] section, we can either put the auth & session config in that section, or use the auth_section option to reference another section containing auth & session config.

L112: cool, I missed that.

I think we should be good with _barbican_opts.copy() and += the remaining opts.

Now I have a new concern, why are we registering the same options into two different groups?

L112 loading.register_session_conf_options(self.conf, _BARBICAN_OPT_GROUP)
L113
L114 loading.register_session_conf_options(self.conf,
                                           _BARBICAN_SERVICE_USER_OPT_GROUP)

I think this will bring confusion when filling option values an probably lead to missconfiguration.

same concern here about using +=, maybe use extend() instead:

In [8]: a = list()

In [9]: a.extend([1, 2, 3])

In [10]: a.extend([4, 5, 6])

In [11]: a
Out[11]: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]
Ack
I think += and extend have the same behaviour here. In this case it's not a problem because loading.get_session_conf_options() creates the returned list.

my concern here is that loading.get_session_conf_options() is being added to two different option groups, and we will eventually consume the values from only one of them. The other one can be a cause of confusion and misconfiguration.
this concern is still valid.

Perhaps. I'm unsure whether the session opts registered in the barbican group will be used. I can try to look into that. However, I would say that is a separate issue from this patch, and any fix required should go in a separate patch.

swift/proxy/controllers/container.py.message: we might want to move this ahead of the _get_from_shards since the resp may now be replaced with a 503, so we lose the opportunity to cache container metadata
slightly off topic but this might also go before _get_from_shards: if the request is not auth'd there's no point building the listing from shards

AFAICT objs is None IFF the backend response is not success or the json.loads() didn't like the response body...so at this point we know we are likely leaving a gap in the listing.

IIRC the thinking back in the days of feature/deep was that this is equivalent to getting an unsharded listing from a container replica that hasn't sync'd or got asyncs yet: that listing may also have gaps.

However, if we're confident there has been an error, as opposed to 'lag', then perhaps it would be better to crash out. My one concern is if we hit this routinely during sharding, if a shard container 404s before being cleaved, but SHARD_LISTING_STATES >= CLEAVED so shard containers should exist before we use them for listing.

Is it worth raising the log level to warning to see how often this is happening?
tests still pass if I change any to all
This definitely seems necessary, but IDK that it's sufficient. I've got a strong suspicion we ought to 503 as soon as we see objs coming back None.
Should maybe bump this up a level or two, and we probably ought to indicate the shard account/container name in the message. IDK that len(objects) is terribly useful info (anymore?)

Oh so this only works because the _get_container_listing only returns None on a !is_successful and error. If there happened to be no objects it'll be an empty [], that it pulled out of the json body.

A comment about None means it was unsuccessful (anything not 2**) might be nice, but not a blocker. I can't think of any other non-successfuls that we would tollerate so returning a 503 makes sense. Will also help us to find and fix any shard listing improvents if we start getting a bunch of 503s 😊

Don't store scripts here. Only systemd units should be placed here. You can put your scripts under the "/opt" directory, or use ansible command to create an appropriate subdirectory under "/opt" for your script.

you need to also "set -o pipefail".
Otherwise your piped operations will only fail if the very last command in the "|" chain fails.

This seems to have a lot of built-in assumptions and not easy to debug or know if it's working as expected. It would be better to break this out, and validate each step (each | operation) behaves as you expect. For example, making sure each | is not blank.

There's no reason to start the service. This code runs in the context of the chroot'd environment used to build the image.
Use "enabled: yes" instead of "state: started". This will create the proper symlinks so that your services will start when the image is actually deployed and boots, but won't start it during the image building process.
